content: I'm in the final subworld of the Logic game world (https://adam.math.hhu.de/#/g/trequetrum/lean4game-logic), and I've mostly solved level 5; I just need to show R, and one of my assumptions is (R → False) → False. This should be straightforward, but I'm struggling to do this: I have been given a "not-not-not" theorem (¬¬¬a → ¬a), but for some reason no "not-not" theorem. I am trying to construct a lambda to demonstrate (¬¬R → R), but struggling to work out how to do this. Please let me know if you have any advice or have any questions about what my other constraints are
Do you have any form of docs#Classical.em ?
You can't prove ¬¬R → R without classical reasoning.
If you have some sort of classical reasoning, then you can do (Classical.em R).elim _ _ and work with two cases, both should be easy to deal with.

Honestly I suspect the allowed theorems did leave a bit of a gap, unfortunately only posing an issue with the approach I took, and not the approaches they considered. I decided to just enable all theorems, and contrapose, and it was simple from there.
JDS has marked this topic as resolved.
In a game that is so close to foundations I suspects that enabling more theorems simply ruins the game.
Of course it gets a lot simpler to show things by assuming them (or very close variations).
Note this isn’t a moral judgement. To me this is a clear sign that you want to do some math instead of logic, and this is definitely fine.

Note also that, even though double negation is not provable without classical logic,  (¬¬¬a → ¬a) is. See for instance https://plfa.github.io/Negation/
While I agree with all of Patrick's comments, all the levels in this game should be solvable without classical logic. Indeed the title of the game is "An Introduction to Constructive Logic"

Perhaps you are right, though I do suspect in this case that I'd dug myself a hole that I unfortunately didn't have tools to dig out of. The whole point of that level was to be tedious and repetitive, and I assume there was some easier approach that I missed, as the final boss level took me significantly less time and effort that that level

Level 5 of the final (bottom) world

In practice you'd definitely just solve this with a rewrite, but this level deliberately takes that away from you. But this means that the proof idea ought to be to swap all the Rs for Ss by hand, and close the goal that way

I don't fully understand why that new goal is that; I would've expected it to be S -> Q (the plan was to show R -> S, and S -> Q, therefore R -> Q). And it opens a new goal (called "Goal 2", there), requiring I prove R, which seems like the thing requiring excluded-middle

The problem is in the unification there, as imp_trans's R is chosen as R → Q instead of simply Q, which causes confusing behaviour. You can use apply imp_trans (R := Q) h1.mp or apply (imp_trans h1.mp : (S → Q) → R → Q)
